text:
Some useful links
• Sharing <@U04SYDF81D5>'s recent documentation on using weblate <https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/pull/142>
• *Some interesting guides, glossaries and handbooks*
    ◦ Turing way translation handbook <https://the-turing-way.netlify.app/community-handbook/translation>
    ◦ R OpenSci's draft of translation guidelines <https://translationguide.ropensci.org/>
    ◦ R OpenSci's glossary <https://github.com/ropensci-review-tools/glossary/blob/master/glossary.csv>
• Translations wiki <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki>

text:
*Goals for the Sprint*:
• Global translation guidelines
• Language-specific guidelines
• List translators for each language (and maybe assign a maintainer per language)
• List reviewers for each language (long-term)
• Linking the R documentation to the wiki
• Documenting the workflow (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/pull/142>)

attachments.text:
Here is my first draft about using Weblate for translating the R message, <https://github.com/hturner|@hturner> <https://github.com/lawremi|@lawremi>

Please, let me know your feedbacks.

elements.text: A WIP document to organize the discussion of general translation guidelines

attachments.text:
```
Traduction de R en français, minidictionnaire:
----------------------------------------------
Rem : respectons la syntaxe française. plaçons un espace devant les ponctuations
telles que :, ;, !, ? (sauf . et ,)
/ : espace avant / après (sauf si c'est un chemin d'accès, par exemple, c:/temp)
par contre, nous conservons les conventions du langage S pour les guillements,
soit '' ou "", mais non transformés et sans espaces.


aborting : annulation
allocation : affectation mémoire
anova : ANOVA
argument : argument (et non paramètre)
array : tableau
assigment : affectation
attribute : attribut
backslash : caractère barre oblique inversée
binary operator : opérateur binaire
bind : lien (binding : lier)
bitmap : bitmap
boxplot : boite à dispersion
breaks : limites de classes (histogrammes, plus parlant que simplement 'limites')
browser : explorateur
bytecode : pseudo-code (code a octets est officiel mais peu utilisé)
cached value : valeur cachée en mémoire
call : appel
callback : rappel (callback)
case insensitive matching : correspondance indépendante de la casse
channel : canal
character : caractère (sans h)
closure : fermeture (closure)
coerce : convertir automatiquement
coercion : conversion automatique
collation : collation
colortype : colorimétrie
connection : connexion
console : console
database : base de données
dataframe : tableau de données, mais on précise (data frame) si nécessaire
deparse : reconstruction de code (deparse)
deprecated : obsolète
device : périphérique
dispatch: dispatcheur
download: téléchargement
driver : pilote
encoding : encodage
environment : environnement (voir aussi workspace)
factor : variable facteur ou facteur
fifo : fifo (préférable à... peps, peu connu)
filename : nom de fichier
file stream : corps du fichier
fit : ajustement ou ajuster
flush : vider ou vidage
formula : formule de modèle ou formule tout court
frame : cadre ou trame selon le contexte
handler : manipulateur de données (voir aussi interrupt handler)
hashing : hachage
Hessian : Hessien
history : historique des commandes
image : image d'environnement (fichier image où les objets R sont sauvés)
implemented : implémenté
index : indice (presque toujours, et non index)
interrupt handler : traitement de l'interruption
invalid : incorrect (à préférer à 'non valide')
IO : E/S
kriging : krigeage
label : étiquette
lag : décalage
layout : mise en page
lazy loading : chargement partiel (explicit loading : chargement complet)
leading minor : mineur dominant
length : longueur (réserver taille pour size)
library : bibliothèque
locale : environnement linguistique
locator : mode de localisation à la souris (pour les graphes)
logical : booléen
log-likelyhood : log de vraisemblance
magic number : nombre magique
metafile : metafile
mirror site : site miroir
mismatch : incohérence
mode : mode
modulus : modulus
multibyte : multioctets
NA : NA ou valeur manquante, selon le contexte
named args : arguments nommés
namespace : espace de noms
non-vector type : type non vectoriel
offset : décalage
opcode : code d'opération
outlier : valeur extrême
overflow : débordement au dépassement de capacité par le haut
package : package (non traduit cf. significations pour paquet ou paquetage)
pager : afficheur
pair list : liste appariée
parse : analyse de code (to parse : analyser le code)
path : chemin d'accès
pattern : motif
pipe : conduite
pixmap : pixmap (format de fichier image)
platform : architecture
polyline : ligne brisée
port : port (sur un serveur TCP/IP par exemple)
profiling : profilage (to profile : profiler)
promise : promesse (promise)
prompt : invite ou invite de commande
proxy : proxy
push back : repoussage
quote symbol : symbole de chaîne de caractères (et non de citation)
raw : raw, si c'est le type de données, sinon brut
range : plage, étendue ou intervalle, selon le contexte
redraw : retraçage (des affichages)
regular expression : expression régulière
report: (to report : signaler)
repository : entrepôt
restore : restaurer
return : retour ou renvoi selon le contexte
RNG : RNG ou générateur de nombres pseudo-aléatoires
routine : sous-programme ou procédure
search path : chemin de recherche
seed : valeurs d'initialisation
seek : mode d'accès aléatoire
self-starting function : fonction auto-initialisée
sequence : suite (selon contexte) ou séquence
shingke : latte (dans lattice)
sink : sortie par défaut
size : taille
slash : caractère barre oblique
slot : slot (sous partie d'un objet S4, terme spécifique de S)
snapshot : instantané graphique
socket : connecteur logiciel (ou socket -usage courant- dans les longs messages)
source : source (to source : sourcer, préférable à entrée par défaut)
specified : fourni (voir choisi ou donné, selon le contexte)
stack : pile
standard deviation : écart type
subscript : indice
subset : sous-ensemble (subsetting : indiçage, ou réalisation d'un sous-ensemble)
table : tableau de contingence
tag : marque
thermometer : jauge (contexte de graphes)
thread :  contexte (threaded code : code contextuel)
timeout : délais maximal
timer : horloge ou temporisation, selon le contexte
timezone : fuseau horaire
top level : niveau le plus haut
traceback : historique des fonctions appelées ('traceback')
trimmed mean : moyenne tronquée
truncation : troncature
type : type
unary operator : opérateur unaire
unbind : délier
underflow : dépassement de capacité par le bas
unmatched : déparié
url : URL
viewport : vue
vignette : vignette
warning : avis (avertissement est bien aussi, mais trop long)
weight : pondération
working directory : répertoire de travail
workspace : environnement de travail (workspace = environment dans R)
ou session s'il s'agit à la fois de l'historique et de l'environnement
wrapup : emballer ou emballage

```
attachments.title: <https://github.com/phgrosjean/rfrench/blob/main/RFrenchDictionary.txt | RFrenchDictionary.txt>

elements.text:
So it seems the "Needs editing" box marks a translation as fuzzy - this is probably too strong as a marker for a translation that needs review (if we were to summarize fuzzy translations in the source, we would assume fuzzy translations are not correct).

I propose the following workflow:
Wait for peer to vote for translation or suggest an alternative.
This would require the peer review workflow to be enabled:

It means translations cannot be added without at least one other person giving the okay, so translation teams would need at least two people. Since R Core cannot check translations, this seems a safer option.

Alternatively, I think we could add all users as reviewers then we would be able to continue as now: any one can add translations, they are marked as "waiting for review", then anyone can mark a translation as "approved" to show that it has undergone 2nd review. Translations "waiting for review" appear as valid in the .po files. This way is more relaxed: we could have a single translator working on a language and all translations go into R-devel, whether they have been approved or not, so there is no delay waiting for review. (This is the Dedicated reviewers workflow:

attachments.fallback:
[April 17th, 2023 1:54 AM] ht: So it seems the "Needs editing" box marks a translation as fuzzy - this is probably too strong as a marker for a translation that needs review (if we were to summarize fuzzy translations in the source, we would assume fuzzy translations are not correct).

I propose the following workflow:

1. Suggest a new translation.
2. Uncheck "needs editing".
3. Wait for peer to vote for translation or suggest an alternative.
This would require the peer review workflow to be enabled:
<https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#peer-review>
It means translations cannot be added without at least one other person giving the okay, so translation teams would need at least two people. Since R Core cannot check translations, this seems a safer option.

Alternatively, I think we could add all users as reviewers then we would be able to continue as now: any one can add translations, they are marked as "waiting for review", then anyone can mark a translation as "approved" to show that it has undergone 2nd review. Translations "waiting for review" appear as valid in the .po files. This way is more relaxed: we could have a single translator working on a language and all translations go into R-devel, whether they have been approved or not, so there is no delay waiting for review. (This is the Dedicated reviewers workflow: <https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#dedicated-reviewers>).

What do people think?
attachments.text:
So it seems the "Needs editing" box marks a translation as fuzzy - this is probably too strong as a marker for a translation that needs review (if we were to summarize fuzzy translations in the source, we would assume fuzzy translations are not correct).

I propose the following workflow:

1. Suggest a new translation.
2. Uncheck "needs editing".
3. Wait for peer to vote for translation or suggest an alternative.
This would require the peer review workflow to be enabled:
<https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#peer-review>
It means translations cannot be added without at least one other person giving the okay, so translation teams would need at least two people. Since R Core cannot check translations, this seems a safer option.

Alternatively, I think we could add all users as reviewers then we would be able to continue as now: any one can add translations, they are marked as "waiting for review", then anyone can mark a translation as "approved" to show that it has undergone 2nd review. Translations "waiting for review" appear as valid in the .po files. This way is more relaxed: we could have a single translator working on a language and all translations go into R-devel, whether they have been approved or not, so there is no delay waiting for review. (This is the Dedicated reviewers workflow: <https://docs.weblate.org/en/latest/workflows.html#dedicated-reviewers>).

What do people think?

text:
I've updated the R Project general info on weblate to include the language team leaders from the <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki/Conventions-for-translations|wiki>.
Please check at <https://translate.rx.studio/projects/r-project/#information> (or the below screenshot) and let me know if you have ideas on how to improve this.
If the team is not happy with the current solution for listing folks (this is a markdown-formatted free text field in Weblate), I can try to look for a plugin that allows better listing of contributors/leaders per language (something like the projects admins listed at the bottom).

Like ROpenSci, The Turing Way, etc

text:
Languages that we want to write conventions for have been hyperlinked on this table: <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/wiki/Conventions-for-translations#languages-and-contributions>

The hyperlink takes you to a template where you can document the language specific conventions.

elements.text: Languages that we want to write conventions for have been hyperlinked on this table:

text: source string locations are now actually click out to the location of terms in the C sources <https://github.com/r-devel/translations/issues/25> :partyr:

attachments.text:
Currently, weblate only shows the source code location (file name + line number), see e.g. <https://translate.rx.studio/translate/r-project/base-r-gui/de/?&offset=3|https://translate.rx.studio/translate/r-project/base-r-gui/de/?&offset=3>

<https://github.com/r-devel/translations/assets/495736/776b53b9-b77a-49a1-a59c-259b7b5576cf|Image>

It would be much nicer if that would point to the actual source code hosted only, e.g. git clone of the SVN repo
attachments.title: #25 Hyperlink source string location
